title: The Impact of Innovation Incentives on Productivity, Income and Employment: Evidence from R&D Subsidies
idea_hypothesis: Increasing innovation.policy_encourage_innovation and innovation.innovation_research_share will increase firms' effective R&D effort, leading to higher productivity and aggregate income and modest employment improvements compared with a baseline of lower encouragement.
method: We conduct a simulation experiment to study the effects of innovation incentive policies on productivity, income, and employment. The experiment employs an Agent-Based Economic Simulation model, comparing a control group and a treatment group. In the control group, policy_encourage_innovation=false, while in the treatment group, policy_encourage_innovation=true, with other parameters held constant (innovation_research_share=0.1). The simulation scale consists of 5 households and 24 firms, running for 4 iterations. We track key macroeconomic indicators including employment rate, unemployment rate, Gini coefficient, average income, savings rate, and firm revenue.
data: We use a simulation platform with the following parameters: system scale of 5 households and 24 firms, running for 4 iterations. Control group settings: innovation.enable_innovation_module=true, innovation.policy_encourage_innovation=false, innovation.innovation_research_share=0.1. Treatment group settings: innovation.enable_innovation_module=true, innovation.policy_encourage_innovation=true, innovation.innovation_research_share=0.1. Other parameters remain consistent, including tax policy (income_tax_rate=0.225) and labor market settings (enable_dynamic_job_posting=true).
experiments:
Key results (treatment vs control):

Employment rate: 0.80 vs 1.00 (−20.0%)
Unemployment rate: 0.20 vs 0.00 (+0.20)
Gini coefficient: 0.4997 vs 0.4414 (+13.2% → more unequal)
Avg monthly income: 5717.98 vs 6708.06 (−14.8%)
Savings rate: 0.5552 vs 0.5534 (+0.3%, ≈ no change)
Avg firm revenue: 8,402,948 vs 8,405,994 (−0.04%)

Interpretation (short-run, small-scale run: 5 households, 4 iterations):

Setting policy_encourage_innovation=true with the same research share (0.1) led to lower income and employment and higher inequality in this brief horizon, with minimal change in firm revenue. This may reflect short-run reallocation costs, insufficient time for innovation to translate into productivity, or parameter mapping where encouragement doesn't immediately boost output. The negative employment effect suggests potential labor market frictions or skill mismatches during the transition period. The increased inequality (Gini coefficient +13.2%) indicates that innovation incentives may initially benefit certain households or firms more than others, potentially due to heterogeneous capabilities in R&D absorption.
